comments.body: Looks like you change this to look for 'user' instead of 'username'. Shouldn't it look for 'username'?
yes, I'm pretty sure we should look for 'user'. we can find the documents in [Linux man page](https://linux.die.net/man/5/ssh_config)
OK, thanks. This looks good then.

Does this work if `self.config['host']` is `None`, e.g. if someone uses a URI like `sftp:///some/path`? Looks like `lookup` might expect a string (see [Paramiko API docs](http://docs.paramiko.org/en/2.4/api/config.html#paramiko.config.SSHConfig.lookup))
This was indeed an issue. I've added a default case. If `self.config['host'] is None`, `self.config['host'] = 'localhost'`.
Will `user_config['identityfile']` always be an array? Would be great to confirm if you're able to, the paramiko docs aren't super clear on this

The ssh_config docs say:
> IdentityFile
> Specifies a file from which the user's RSA or DSA authentication identity is read. The default is ~/.ssh/identity for protocol version 1, and ~/.ssh/id_rsa and ~/.ssh/id_dsa for protocol version 2. Additionally, any identities represented by the authentication agent will be used for authentication.
>The file name may use the tilde syntax to refer to a user's home directory or one of the following escape characters: '%d' (local user's home directory), '%u' (local user name), '%l' (local host name), '%h' (remote host name) or '%r' (remote user name).
>It is possible to have multiple identity files specified in configuration files; all these identities will be tried in sequence.

So one would assume that IdentityFile will be an array. In my case, the returned array has length 1.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +45,49 @@
            if 'identityfile' in user_config:
                self.config['private_key'] = user_config['identityfile'][0]

            self.sftp = pysftp.Connection(**self.config)
